summary: This is an email exchange between a prosecutor and another individual discussing the maximum sentence for Ghislaine Maxwell, noting that the maximum sentences for the offenses were lower during the 1994-97 time period of the charges than they are at the time of writing in 2020.

persons.name: Nicholas Biase
persons.context: Appears as a recipient and sender in an email exchange regarding Ghislaine Maxwell's sentencing, identified with the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS).

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the email discussion, concerning the maximum sentence for her offenses related to charges from the 1994-97 period.

connections.description: Biase, as a prosecutor, is involved in the legal case against Maxwell, discussing sentencing parameters.

events.title: Time period of charges against Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The time period during which the offenses charged against Ghislaine Maxwell allegedly occurred.

events.title: Email discussion on Maxwell's sentencing
events.description: Email exchange discussing the maximum possible sentence for Ghislaine Maxwell, noting differences in sentencing laws between the time of the offenses and 2020.

keyFacts: The document is an email exchange from July 6, 2020, involving prosecutor Nicholas Biase.
It discusses the maximum sentence for Ghislaine Maxwell, noting the charges relate to the period 1994-1997.
It reveals that the maximum sentences for the offenses were lower in 1994-97 than they were in 2020.
The correspondence indicates ongoing legal preparation and discussion regarding Maxwell's prosecution and sentencing.
